The repre≈øentations of former writers on this ≈øubject were roundly denied; the facts they ≈øtated were not only contradicted, but deemed impo≈ø≈øible, and the authors them≈øelves were accu≈øed of ≈ølander. 'Whereas the extreme cruelty and inhumanity of the managers, over≈øeers, and book-keepers of e≈øtates, have frequently driven ≈ølaves into the woods, and occa≈øioned rebellions, internal in≈øurrections, &c. Other preambles of a ≈øimilar complexion, re≈øpecting the lodging, food, and clothes of negroes, are here to be met with. We al≈øo find that run-away negroes, when adverti≈øed, are de≈øcribed by the various brands upon their ≈øhoulders, brea≈øts, cheeks, and foreheads. A woman is de≈øcribed with a wooden leg; a man as having both his ears cropt, and another by his no≈øe and ears being cut off.' Cornwall Chronicle, Nov. 7, 1789. The FIRST CHAPTER contains an account of the Enormities committed by the Natives of Africa on the per≈øons of one another, to procure ≈ølaves for the Europeans, proved by the te≈øtimony of ≈øuch as have vi≈øited that continent‚Äîand confirmed by accounts from the ≈ølaves them≈øelves, after their arrival in the We≈øt-Indies.

Under this head, we learn that Kidnapping, or as the natives call it, Panyaring, is very common, that war is made on purpo≈øe to procure ≈ølaves. Various in≈øtances are mentioned of con≈øummate treachery employed in making captives. Kidnapping is profe≈ø≈øionally followed; large parties go up the country three
hundred miles to drive down captives‚Äîthey go a wood ranging, and pick up every one they meet, and ≈øtrip them naked. The purcha≈øers generally ≈øay, they do not care how the ≈øellers come by their ≈ølaves. Many are ≈øold for crimes fal≈øely imputed; the Judges participate the profits of the ≈øale, and are therefore ≈øtrongly induced to condemn the innocent. Crimes are invented and multiplied for the purpo≈øe of traffic. The great men dre≈øs up and employ women, to entice young men to be connected with them, that they may be convicted of adultery and ≈øold. The ≈ølaves are ≈øeparated without the lea≈øt regard to ties of con≈øanguinity, or the pathetic expo≈øtulations and remon≈øtrances of nature. The man, invited to drink with his neighbour, on ri≈øing to go, is ≈øeized by two of them and a large dog: and this mode of ≈øeizure is common.

By the Second Chapter it appears that the Europeans, by means of the trade in ≈ølaves, are the occa≈øion of the before-mentioned enormities; that they ≈øometimes u≈øe additional means to excite the natives to practi≈øe them, often attempt them≈øelves to ≈øteal the natives, and ≈øucceed, force trade as they plea≈øe, and are guilty of inju≈øtice in their dealings. It is not uncommon to make the natives drunk, and then buy them. We then meet with as oppo≈øite an exhibition of character as can po≈ø≈øibly be conceived: three or four hundred Africans cruelly ma≈ø≈øacreed or carried off, by means of the treacherous contrivance of ≈øix Engli≈øh captains in Old Calabar River. The Third Chapter contains an account of the tran≈øactions of the en≈ølaved Africans, and of the method of confining, airing, feeding, and exerci≈øing them; incidents on the pa≈ø≈øage, and the manner of ≈øelling them when arrived at their de≈øtined ports; the deplorable ≈øituation of the refu≈øe or ≈øickly ≈ølaves; ≈øeparation of relations and friends; mortality on the pa≈ø≈øage, and frequently after ≈øale; and the cau≈øes of this mortality.
